description: The noun is from dialectal (Northern) English, from Middle English gome, from Old Norse gaum, gaumr (‚Äúheed, attention‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *gaum≈ç (‚Äúattention‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *g ∞owe- (‚Äúto heed, pay attention‚Äù). The verb is from Middle English *gomen, from the noun. Compare native Middle English yemen, from Old English ƒ°ƒ´eman (‚Äúto care for, heed‚Äù), and Gothic êå≤êå∞êåøêåºêåæêå∞êåΩ (gaumjan, ‚Äúobserve‚Äù).

examples: "S'cat! s'cat! ‚Äî set that cat off that barns knee ‚Äî it al puzzum it!"
"Ah've tel'd 'em awal abart that tu monny a hunderd times, bud thuh tak no moar gaum o' muh then a stoop."

verbs.description: gaum (third-person singular simple present gaums, present participle gauming, simple past and past participle gaumed)

examples: "We said nowt on 't. Ther' no 'casion to stir up trouble. But we all gaumed 'at when he heerd t' sounds o' them 'at com to lowse us he'd crawled off into t' workin's an' brayed his head agean a shou'der o' quartz."

description: Uncertain; perhaps a variant of gum.

verbs.description: gaum (third-person singular simple present gaums, present participle gauming, simple past and past participle gaumed)

entries.meaning: (US and UK, dialects, chiefly Midlands, Southern US, Appalachia) To smear.
examples: No, bubby, couldn't hev the wax. Gaum him all up so 't mammy 'd hafter nigh abaout skin him tu git him clean ag'in;  [‚Ä¶]

description: Unknown. Possibly related to gaum (‚Äúsmear‚Äù, verb).

examples: "douse your head under the pump and wash some of the gaum off your hands and we'll see what your Aunt Debbie can do for that empty feelin'."

entries.meaning: (dialectal, rare) A bit, a small amount.
examples: When he had let what he deemed was a sufficiency of blood out of the incised vein, he called to Elvira to bring a spoon of "sut" from off the back of the fireplace and a "gaum" of spiderwebs from somewhere or other.

description: Probably a variant of gom (an Irish English slang term for a foolish person), but possibly related to or influenced by gorming, gawming (‚Äúclumsy, stupid‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (rare, dialectal or colloquial) A useless person.
examples: I saw standing up out of the grass a murderous length of sharp steel. Some gaum of a farm boy had abandoned this scythe while cutting bundles of sourgrass for cattle-breeding.

description: Variant of gorm (‚Äúto make a mess of‚Äù), which see for more.

verbs.description: gaum (third-person singular simple present gaums, present participle gauming, simple past and past participle gaumed)

entries.meaning: Alternative form of gorm (to make a mess of).
